turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear argument next in No. 78-6885, Hicks v. Oklahoma.
Mr. Ebel.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
This is a sentencing procedures case and it raises important constitutional questions about the procedures that need to be followed in sentencing defendants.

This is not a case that challenges inherently habitual sentencing statutes, and it is not a case that challenges the excessiveness of a 40-year sentence for a person who commits the kind of crimes that the defendants Hicks has committed.
Rather, it is a case that challenges the method of imposing that sentence on him.
Hicks is a young black man.
He was 28 years old at the time of the trial.
He and his codefendant were convicted by a jury in Oklahoma of a single sale of heroin worth $50.

Now, Oklahoma has a peculiar statute which says that a defendant in Oklahoma has a right to be sentenced by a jury, and the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals has said that that is a sacred right that may not be lost except by express waiver.
Now, because neither defendant here waived that right, the jury was reconvened to sentence these two defendants.
Hicks' codefendant received the minimum sentence possible under the heroin statute, that is five years.
Hicks, on the other hand, was charged under the habitual criminal statute in Oklahoma.
And I should pause for a minute to tell you that Oklahoma has two habitual criminal statutes, 51(A) and 51(B).

51(B) is a mandatory statute and it says that if you have been convicted of two prior felonies, you must be sentenced to the maximum term permissible under the third offense plus an additional 20 years, and that formula here would calculate to a 40-year sentence for Hicks.
Now, the other statute is 51(A) and that is a discretionary statute.
That statute says that if you committed one or more prior offenses, that the jury may sentence you to anything it wishes between ten years and life.
Well, at Hicks trial the jury was given evidence of two prior felony convictions.

Hicks did not challenge that evidence, so the judge instructed the jury that if you find Hicks as guilty of the two prior felonies, you must find him guilty under 51(B) and you must sentence him to 40 years in jail.
The jury listened to those instructions carefully and it followed them and it returned a 40-year mandatory habitual criminal sentence against him.

Now, while that case was pending on appeal, the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals decided a second case that was called Thigpen v. State, and in that case the Oklahoma court held that 51(B) was unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you think Thigpen rested on state constitutional grounds or federal constitutional grounds?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor, I think it rested on federal constitutional grounds, although it doesn't say so in the opinion, and my opinion that it rests on federal grounds rests on the fact that the appendix attached to the opinion is premised upon federal grounds, and it appears to have been cited with approval by the majority opinion.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The District Court of Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So when you said a little while ago that Oklahoma has two statutes, you really mean now it has only one?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, now it has one.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if we were to conclude that Thigpen was incorrectly, decided as a matter of federal constitutional law?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, I think, Your Honor, that that issue isn't directly before this Court because Thigpen was not appealed here.

At least when Hicks was sentenced at the Court of Criminal Appeals, I think that Thigpen represented the law as interpreted by Oklahoma, and so for the case at least of Hicks we can assume that 51(B) was improper.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, there is a certain abstraction about the whole thing perhaps on both sides.
The Oklahoma legislature passes a statute, the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals says it is unconstitutional on federal grounds.
Say this Court now were in this particular proceeding to conclude that that conclusion was wrong.
The statute is still in existence, it is just two courts have expressed two different opinions as to whether or not it is constitutional.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: No, I don't think the statute is in existence any more because it has been declared unconstitutional by a final decision by the state's highest court before this case ever came up here.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your view is that unless the state took an appeal to this Court on the assumption that there was a federal question involved, they have acquiesced in that matter?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct.
I think it might be said to be bad law today.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Let me ask you this Supposing that after Thigpen had been decided and after this case had been decided one way or the other, this Court were to come down with a square ruling that indicated that made clear that Thigpen was wrongly decided if it rested on federal constitutional grounds, would you then say that Oklahoma legislature had to enact a new statute rather than simply having the old one revived?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Oh, absolutely, Your Honor.

I think that once Thigpen is final and not appealed, that that statute is invalidated because the law changes, it doesn't spring back, all the legislation around the country that might have been stricken under one interpretation of the law.
I think the legislature would clearly have to reenact the statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is your authority for that?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I don't have any to cite to you at this time, Your Honor, but I believe that to be the law.
We cite in this case both due process and equal protection and Eighth Amendment arguments.
Because of the shortness of time, I am going to argue primarily the due process case issues here, as I think it is primarily a procedural case.
Our first due process argument is that Hicks was denied due process when he was sentenced in violation of the state's own laws.
Now, there is no doubt that Oklahoma has created a right to be sentenced by a jury.
The Oklahoma statute 926 explicitly says so.
The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals has explicitly said that there is such a right and it is sacred.

The state in its responsive brief at page 24 acknowledges this fact when it says, "Although the United States Constitution does not mandate the imposition of punishment by a jury, the State of Oklahoma has statutorily created such a right."

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When Thigpen was decided during the pendency of this appeal, could the state have gone back to the process of new sentencing?
You would have to reconstitute the original jury, would you, if you were to try that?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I don't think you need to reconstitute the original jury, Your Honor.
I think that the statute simply requires a jury sentencing.
It doesn't say that it has to be the same jury, so I think it could be a new jury.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If we hypothetically agreed with you now, would Oklahoma assemble a jury and go through the sentencing process under the surviving statute?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Yes, I believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And he might get 40 years or he might not get 40 years.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is mandatory under 51(B) but permissive under 51(A), is that correct?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, and 51(B) is what has been thrown out and which we think is now a final decision in the State of Oklahoma.
So unless it were reenacted, 51(A) is the statute under which they would have to proceed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You probably can't tell us, but was there any indication that you are aware of that the state considered that possibility?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Of reenacting 51(B)?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, of a new sentencing, remanding.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor, there appears to be no indication that the Court of Criminal Appeals considered that.
They just simply said we are going to impose a new sentence under 51(A) because it is not going to prejudice you, since we are going to issue the same length of sentence as before.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you say that when the Supreme Court did that, they were usurping the jury's function.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Perhaps the state will tell us about that a little later.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: All right.

Your Honor, there is no doubt that the sentence here was issued by the Court of Criminal Appeals rather than the jury because the defendant Hicks does come before this Court sentenced only under 51(A) and the jury never purported to issue any sentence under 51(A) itself, only the Court of Appeals presumed to do that.
Further, 51(A) requires the exercise of discretion and the jury never presumed to exercise discretion.
In fact, it was instructed that it could not exercise discretion.
Only the Court of Appeals --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I want to be sure I understand your position.
I did not read the Court of Appeals opinion as imposing a new sentence.
I thought they affirmed the sentence that has been imposed mandatorily before.

They said we must -- all they said, in one sentence, we must find, however, that the defendant was not prejudiced by the use of this statute in that the sentence imposed is within the range of punishment authorized by 51(A).
Does that say they have imposed the sentence themselves?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor, they didn't impose a new length of sentence, they incorporated the old length but they based the sentence upon a different statute.

And under Brown v. State in Oklahoma, and another case that we also cite in our briefs, as well as the Lang case decided by this Court, a sentence under an unconstitutional statute is void, is gone, there is nothing to it.
Oklahoma law says that.
And they have said that 51(B) was unconstitutional, so under Oklahoma's own law the sentence under 51(B) has disappeared.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, they don't say that.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, the Oklahoma --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You may be right as a matter of Oklahoma law, but that is not what their opinion says.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, I think, Your Honor, it in essence does say that because it says that we are going to sentence under 51(A), it is a different statutory --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It does not say that.
That is my very point, it does not say we are going to sentence under 51(A).

It simply says that the defendant was not prejudiced by the use of this statute in that the sentence imposed -- and they are referring to the one imposed by the jury, as I read it -- is within the range authorized by 51(A).
That doesn't say we're imposing a sentence under 51(A) as I read it anyway.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor --
I don't know if it makes any difference, but I just raise this question.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I understand your point to be that the jury was instructed that it had to return a 40year sentence, is that it?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: If the jury was instructed it had to return a 40-year sentence if it found that Hicks had two prior felony convictions.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And there is no dispute that he had two prior felonies?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: No dispute.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So I take it your argument is now that the court was exercising a discretion which under 51(A) could only be exercised by a jury which might have given only a ten-year bonus instead of a twenty-year bonus.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But Justice Stevens is quite right, the court didn't say this flatly.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, the court may not have used the word "resentenced," but the court has said everything but that.

The Oklahoma law, as I said, which isn't disputed, I don't believe, that the sentence under 51(B) is void, either there is a new sentence imposed on Hicks or he stands today with no sentence at all, and I am sure the state isn't going to say he stands with no sentence at all.
And if he doesn't stand under a sentence that was valid under the jury, somebody has had to put a new sentence on him and that somebody has to have been the Court of Criminal Appeals.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I'm not sure you are making your strongest argument.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, if that is true, then several things have happened that have violated Hicks' due process rights.
First, this sentence was imposed by somebody other than the jury, and we think that that violates one of Oklahoma's sacred rights.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that doesn't involve a federal question, does it?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Oh, I think it does, Your Honor.

The way we read the due process clause, a state has to follow its own procedures when substantive and substantial rights are involved, and if it deviates from its own procedures in forms of substantive rights, that is a violation of the due process clause.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You mean if a -- do you think it is unconstitutional for an appellate court to sentence?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I mean a state appellate court to sentence.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I think if the laws permit it and if the appellate court gives the defendant notice and a hearing, then an appellate court may impose sentence.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, if an Oklahoma appellate court from time to time says it is not inconsistent with Oklahoma law in any way, every now and then we will just sentence ourselves when we think the defendant deserves it, the state statute may say something but we will just sentence him ourselves.
Does that violate some federal constitutional --

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I think so.

I think the due process clause says that the law and order applies to the state, to the court as well as to the citizens, and if the state and the courts decide that every now and then we are just not going to follow our law because it is more convenient for us not to, the due process clause doesn't permit that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But isn't the state court's reading of its own law the final version of it so far as we are concerned?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, the state court here never interpreted 926 as having been abrogated by any abilities that it had.
It never said that its rights to modify sentences could be used to cut off a jury right.

The state court never interpreted the law in that regard and this Court in the retention doctrine has said that when there is a clear state statute it can rely on that state statute without looking to any requirement that the state's highest court interpret that statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But isn't there a presumption of validity to a conviction coming from a state court that the state has at least insofar as its own laws are concerned read those laws as they had to be read because it is the final interpreter of them?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I don't know of any presumption of validity, Your Honor.
I think that the due process clause doesn't have such a presumption, and this Court can look at the procedures and see if the court has followed the law.
I don't know of any law here that gives a greater presumption to a court that may not be following its own state law than it does to any other state official that may not be following state law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That just assumes that it isn't following its own law.

Brother Rehnquist says and suggests to you that the Oklahoma law is what the Oklahoma court says it is, and if the Oklahoma statute says jury sentencing but the Oklahoma Supreme Court says, well, from time to time we can sentence ourselves in the right circumstances and that this is not inconsistent with Oklahoma law, how does that violate the Constitution?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, the Oklahoma court didn't say that what it was doing was not inconsistent with Oklahoma law.
It didn't say this is not inconsistent with your jury rights.
It sais simply this doesn't prejudice you, and I am saying it does prejudice Hicks.
They are not saying that Oklahoma law doesn't give Hicks a jury right.
They are saying we can do this because we don't think it is prejudicial to you, and I think it was prejudicial to Hicks.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There is nothing implicit in that.
Isn't there a holding also that it is not a contravention of their own state constitution?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, if there is such an implicit holding, then I think state courts are courts are virtually immune from any challenge that they are not following their own laws.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It has to be implicit.
You don't think they said to themselves, oh, we are going to do this but we think it violated the federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I don't --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: They must have implicitly thought that it didn't.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I think what they said was this may not comply with all the procedural safeguards we have, but we don't think it is prejudicing Hicks and so why does he care, because we are going to give him the same length of sentence.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The question here is whether there is some federal constitutional right.
You said that you thought that federal constitutional rights were violated in several respects.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: You have given us one.
Do you have another one?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
The other one is we think that the federal Constitution requires notice and hearing before you can impose a sentence and that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Before the Supreme Court of the state could impose the sentence?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Before anyone can impose a sentence.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the only one that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The court didn't say that.
The court said that we think the sentence is all right, but they didn't impose it.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where did the Court of Appeals say we sentence you to blank years?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They didn't say that, did they?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, the strongest syllogism I can argue on that is that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I am not asking for syllogism, I am asking for facts.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, they said that we are sentencing you -- they said you were sentenced under 51(B), that is an unconstitutional statute, but we don't think you are prejudiced if we affirm a 40-year sentence under 51(A).

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, isn't affirming different from sentencing?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, I think it is a different word but I think it means the same thing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, they said we agree with you, Mr. Hicks, that the statute under which you were sentenced is unconstitutional.
It would then follow, I suppose, that he was not sentenced at all.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It was a void or invalid sentence.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That is what Oklahoma law says.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Therefore, if he is under any sentence at all, it has to be as a result of his sentence imposed by the Supreme Court of Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you say the Supreme Court has no authority to fix it at this 20 extra years.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: What I would argue on the second point, Your Honor, is that we think the U.S. Constitution requires the defendant to have an opportunity for notice and a hearing before a sentence can be imposed, and we think that Hicks here did not have such an opportunity to present any evidence on his behalf under 51(A), and that that violates the United States Constitution quite apart from any of your readings of the Oklahoma law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you think the only remedy available by the time the appeal was argued in the state Supreme Court was to send it back to the trial court for a new sentencing procedure under 51(A)?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Because, as Mr. Justice Stewart suggested, at the time of the oral argument in that court, the Supreme Court, there was no valid sentence outstanding.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Right, and the Oklahoma court cases are absolutely explicit on that point, the Brown case and the other one that I cite in my brief.
When the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals faced Hicks and said that 51(B) was unconstitutional, Hicks stood before them without a valid sentence at all.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I understood you to say before that you would be quite satisfied if the -- even if your client were not, as matter of law you would be quite satisfied if this Court were to have the case go back down through the Supreme Court to the trial court for resentencing under the procedure of 51(A).

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you might --

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor, not necessarily under 51(A), because our third argument is that we think 51(A) itself is unconstitutional on its face, but at least we would be satisfied if he were resentenced and we think the sentence ought to be conducted under the basic heroin statute rather than 51(A), but at least to be sentenced.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That would avoid the enhancement of the sentence?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct, and it would entitle him to be punished somewhere between five years and twenty which is the spread permitted under the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then my first assumption has fallen apart, hasn't it, that you would be satisfied if it went back for resentencing.
I thought you had told me earlier that you wanted to be resentenced under 51(A) in my prior questions to you.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor, what I meant to say was that we would be satisfied with resentencing.
We are not asking to reopen the guilt phase of this trial, and we think that resentencing could be under a newly constituted jury and would not need to be under the old jury.

If I said that we would be satisfied with resentencing under 51(A), I misspoke because our third due process argument is that 51(A) is unconstitutional on its face because it is excessively broad and gives no standards and direction for the jury in the sentencing process, and we think therefore the proper sentence would be under the heroin statute.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That never having been decided in the Oklahoma court, it would be no question for us to reach here, would it?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, it was not presented before the Oklahoma court, Your Honor.
I think, however, that under a variety of doctrines that this Court has articulated in the past, which you are very familiar with, it could be reached by this Court for judicial economy, that is --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Are you talking about the state court, when the issue hasn't been raised and passed on by the state court?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, I think that that would be --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Isn't that a jurisdictional question here?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, I think if this Court remands for sentencing under 51(A) and Hicks gets his sentence under 51(A) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, we wouldn't necessarily remand for sentence under 51(A), we would just remand.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, if Hicks then is resentenced under --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: For resentencing.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I would say if Hicks is sentenced under 51(A), then we would have to come back before this Court to challenge --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That is old hat, if this particular federal constitutional issue were not raised in the state court, if the validity of that statute wasn't raised and passed on, I don't think we can reach it here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't it true generally, Mr. Ebel, that in Oklahoma juries are given wide latitude in imposing sentences?
You have told us already --

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that a defendant has a right to be sentenced by the jury in most cases --

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- without any standards, and that 51(A) which provides for repeat offenders, gives the jury discretion to impose any sentence between ten years and life, if I am not mistaken.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is quite typical of Oklahoma sentencing procedures?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I would --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It is longer than most, but typical in giving the jury no standards, and allowing the jury wide discretion.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: I think that the typical statute in Oklahoma does not set any standards for the jury, but most of the statutes are like the heroin statute with a narrow range of five years to twenty, which we think is permissible.
And the only statute that I know of in Oklahoma that allows --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that range may seem narrow to you or me, but I don't know if it would be for the person sentenced.
There is quite a difference between five years and twenty.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: When it is out of your own life.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You raise Eighth Amendment questions, too, I take it?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And equal protection?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Are you just submitting them in your brief or --

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Your Honor, I think probably I don't have the time to go into those in care.

The equal protection argument that I would assert primarily is that the state has treated two categories of people differently, those that were originally sentenced under 51(A) and those like Hicks who were originally sentenced under 51(B) and then resentenced under 51(A).

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How many of these issues that you are relying on here did you assert as constitutional federal issues in the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: The only two that clearly were not raised below were our third and fourth due process arguments, that is the lack of standards in the sentence and the failure of the court to give any reasons for its sentence.

Beyond that, it is a little hard to tell exactly what was raised because the constitutional arguments asserted below just broadly speak about violation of the United States Constitution and they did not articulate due process, equal amendment or Eighth Amendment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You didn't argue the case then in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: No.
I am court appointed by this Court to represent Hicks here on certiorari.

He was represented by the public defender below to the decision of the Court of Criminal Appeals, and when the Court of Criminal Appeals sentenced him under 51(A), he carried the case on then pro se himself and filed his petition for certiorari in this Court pro se and was granted pro se.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Ebel, one of your due process arguments, as I understand it, is that whoever fixes the sentence, there should have been notice and an opportunity on behalf of the defendant to argue what the sentence should be.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But he did not receive that in the trial court because the jury was instructed that there was a mandatory requirement of forty years, and he didn't receive it in the Court of Appeals because the Court of Appeals imposed the sentence.

Now, if we should accept that argument, would it not be the appropriate relief simply to send it back to the Oklahoma Court without any instructions about jury sentencing, because presumably as far as the federal Constitution is concerned the Court of Appeals can do its own sentencing, as long as they gave you a fair opportunity to say that what the sentence should be before they simply affirm on the basis of an invalid trial court action.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, unless it is accepted by this Court that there is a right to be sentenced by a jury in Oklahoma and the failure to observe that right is itself a due process violation.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, we could send it back to the Court of Appeals and they could decide whether there is such a right in Oklahoma which they would be much better able to decide than we would.
Presumably, if they thought there was they would follow their own law, I think we have to presume that.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Well, we think, Your Honor, that the Oklahoma law is already clear on that, and this Court can decide that on the basis presented by the Court of Criminal Appeals which was that Hicks wasn't prejudiced.
And I think this Court could say that it was, he was and it needs to be sent back for a jury to sentence.
Your Honor, I see that my light light is thrown on and I would like to reserve a few moments for rebuttal, so I will rest.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Cox.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
Opposing counsel and myself do not differ on the basic premise that the sentencing stage of a trial proceeding is protected by the due process clause of the 14th Amendment.
The difference between my position and the position of my opposing counsel is that there is a determination that needs to be made as to what process is due.

The petitioner argues that the failure of the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals to remand this cause for jury sentencing deprived him of a procedural right under section 926 of the Oklahoma Constitution.

The petitioner has gone through the facts adequately, but I think it is important for this Court to understand exactly what the Court of Criminal Appeals did in Thigpen v. State when it invalidated section 51(B) which was the sentencing provision under which petitioner in this case was sentenced.
The court made a determination and an interpretation upon the basis of the intent of the legislature in this case to provide the progressively greater punishment for the habitual offender.
Under 51(B), the punishment was restricted and there was a classification that a second subsequent offender would receive, as in this case forty years.
Had Mr. Hicks been tried under 51(A) he could have received a possible sentence of life.

Based upon that premise, the Court of Criminal Appeals did not invalidate the sentencing statute on the basis of a constitutional issue, especially on the basis of due process, but merely that it did not comport with the intent of the legislature to provide for progressively greater punishment.
Now, the petitioner's entire argument is predicated on the fact that the invalidation of 51(B) completely voided his sentence, and this is not true.

So long as the sentencing statute contains the severability clause, which in this case it did -- and I must remind this Court that we are not talking about two statutes, we are talking about one that merely said divided two classes of individuals, that being habitual offenders.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Ms. Cox, may I just be sure I understand you.
Are you saying that the Oklahoma Supreme Court or Court of Criminal Appeals, whichever it was, in Thigpen did not hold 51(B) unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I am saying that they held it to be vague and illusory and because it --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand.
Did they hold it to be unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Yes, they did hold it unconstitutional but not on the basis of the federal constitutional issue, that it denied due process.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So we must accept that as a matter of state law that statute is unconstitutional, is that true?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That is correct, and we are not trying to litigate the constitutionality of 51(B) but only as to what the court tried to do when it invalidated the statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Then you disagree with your opposing counsel that Thigpen was based on federal constitutional grounds?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I do.
I believe it was an interpretation of a state statute based upon state law and procedure.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: For purposes of this case, it probably doesn't make any difference, does it?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, it really doesn't except that he has predicated the invalidation of section 51(B) on the fact that it voided the petitioner's sentence and therefore the Court of Criminal Appeals in effect resentenced the petitioner.
And what I am trying to say --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That would be true regardless of the basis for declaring 51(B) unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Hypothetically, if this case went back, have you suggested that the new jury could give a life sentence in the exercise of its discretion?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Yes, I have, Your Honor.
Unfortunately, the state of Oklahoma does not have any procedural device which would reempanel a new jury.
I am also arguing that the Court of Criminal Appeals exercised its authority under section 1066 to either modify, affirm, remand or otherwise reverse a case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, Ms. Cox, you are emphasizing that and you have argued that and it is very clear from the statute that the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals does have that revisory authority.
May I ask you this Do you know of any case where the Court of Criminal Appeals has increased a jury-imposed sentence in the exercise of that authority?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
In fact, I believe that they would be prohibited from increasing a sentence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If they have acted at all, they have only decreased one?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Yes, that's correct, either the same sentence or decrease it, which they have done under the decisions following Thigpen where the defendants were sentenced under section 51(B).
In some cases they have modified and in some cases they have affirmed them.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But when you modify, it is only to decrease?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Decrease, yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You know of no case and in fact you doubt the power of the court to increase a sentence imposed by a jury.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I think it would be highly improper and an exercise of --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In any event, you know of no case where that was done?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, Your Honor, there has been none.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In fact, isn't that what was done here?
If there was no jury sentence and they imposed a forty-year sentence, didn't they increase it by forty years?
And if so, haven't you acknowledged that the action was improper?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: If you buy the premise that the sentence was void.
What I am trying to distinguish from here is the right to resentence by jury under 926 and the asserted right of petitioner to be resentenced following appellate review.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, is it your view -- let me just be sure I understand your theory.
Is it your view that what the Court of Appeals in effect did was affirm the sentence imposed by the jury?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then where did the defendant get his opportunity to have somebody decide how long he should be in jail?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Because at the trial court level he was given an opportunity during the second stage of the proceedings to be represented by counsel to attack the underlying convictions.
That was all that due process requires in this case.
We are talking about two separate levels.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You said a moment ago that due process applies to the sentencing procedure.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: It does in the sense that the trial court level, and that is what we are talking about in this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what due process was there if he had a right to have the jury decide between ten and forty and the judge said to the jury, you must give him forty?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Because the sentencing statute, 51(B), required a mandatory imposition of 40 years.
This Court has already hold that that type of an instruction, in Rummel v. Estella last week, is not improper.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Except it was simply invalid in this case.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That is what petitioner argues, it was simply invalid.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Maybe not improper if there had been a valid statute authorizing it, but there wasn't.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I would --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you think if they went back and did it all over again, the judge could give the same instruction?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Well, section 51(B) has been reenacted, and that portion which would provide for the maximum under the underlying felony has been deleted from the statute.
I am not saying that he would be resentenced under 51(B), but the same --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So your answer is that the same instruction could not be given.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's correct, because the statute has been amended.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then how can you defend the procedure in the trial court that was followed?
I don't understand your argument.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Because due process only affords the right for him to be represented by counsel to attack the underlying convictions.

The petitioner in this case relies upon the case of Klimas and in that case the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals was presented with a problem similar to this case only they did not determine that the underlying statute was invalid.
What they determined was that the defendant had been prejudiced because during the second stage certain convictions had been improperly admitted upon which the jury was considering the punishment.
They felt that this afforded him substantial prejudice and reversed it and sent it back for resentencing.
We don't have that problem in this case.
The same evidence would be admitted at the trial court level on a second hearing in this case as in the first one, even though the mandatory punishment statute could not be given as an instruction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose he was resentenced before another jury under different instructions, could he say anything to the jury?
The jury would have the sentencing power, couldn't he say anything to the jury about sentencing?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Oklahoma does not prohibit a defendant from coming before the jury to present mitigating circumstances during the second stage.
In this particular instance, the defendant chose to stand mute as a procedural trial tactic.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But what good would it have done to present mitigating circumstances when the jury is told by the judge you've got to give him forty years?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That is correct, but this Court has upheld --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He still waives his right to do it, you say.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: When does the judge instruct the jury in Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Following the presentation of the evidence and closing arguments by counsel, then he instructs the jury.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So he is the last -- does counsel know what the instructions are going to be before they argue?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Yes.
In fact, in this case there was in the opinion --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So they had been absolutely told what his instruction was going to be?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The jury was going to be instructed that --

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: In other words --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that isn't much of a hearing then on sentencing, is it?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Well, the information put him on notice, put the petitioner on notice when the charges were originally filed.
He knew what his sentence was going to be.
He knew what he had to defend against.
This is the essence of due process.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could he have been sentenced under 51(A)?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, he did not qualify under that class.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How can anyone be sentenced under -- as I understand it, the Court of Criminal Appeals said that the jury could have sentenced him under 51(A).
The court said that the defendant was not prejudiced by the rules of this statute in that the sentence imposed is within the range of punishment authorized by the provisions of 51(A).

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: What the court did when it invalidated 51(B) was take away that class of individuals and lumped them all to 51(A).
That is where the court came with the -- in Thigpen they were trying to protect those --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Isn't that shifting the rules?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I don't know what type of rules you are talking about.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you said when he was originally tried, he couldn't have been sentenced under 51(A), but the Court of Criminal Appeals said he could have.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, they merely affirmed the punishment as being within the limits of --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They affirmed 51(B)?
They said they couldn't affirm 51(B) so they affirmed 51(A).

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, they merely said that the sentence was in the range of punishment that the legislature provided for the enhancement of habitual offenders.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So if you have a death penalty for first degree murder and five years for manslaughter, if they sentence you to the death penalty to life imprisonment for manslaughter, that is all right because they could have sent you to death.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Not if that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: There is something wrong with that.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, that creates -- let's talk about the death penalty cases in Furman where a number of states had numerous individuals on death row.
This Court invalidated, especially in Woodson, the death penalty.
The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals invalidated those sentences and commuted them to life, and it is the same analogy that we have in this case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, they didn't commute this sentence, they affirmed it.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, but it is the same type of theory because they have the authority to affirm the sentence of the jury if they find that there is no --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They could affirm an unconstitutional sentence?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: As they --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They could affirm an unconstitutional sentence?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: This Court has to look to Thigpen as to why the court declared it unconstitutional.
It was because its practical application resulted in --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, do you think that this case reversed Thigpen?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, no, it definitely does not reverse Thigpen at all.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then how can you affirm?
They didn't, that is why they used 51(A), because they couldn't affirm it on 51(B) because they had just decided Thigpen.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: If anything, the court could have remanded the cause.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It is interesting, yes.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: It is an interesting question, but the court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It sure is.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: The only remedy the court had --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But this man got forty years.
It is not interesting to him, he has got forty years.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: What they were saying is that in terms of due process he was afforded his hearing, his notice and simply because he was sentenced under a statute which was subsequently found to be unconstitutional, and I think we have to look at the intent of the legislature -- the intent of the Court of Criminal Appeals.
They did not ask that their decision apply retroactively.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The Court of Appeals reaffirmed that this statute was unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: They merely acknowledged --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The merely said it was unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: They concede in their opinion and we agree.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: From the way I read it, it was unconstitutional before Thigpen, according to what the court said.
The court said and it was laid to rest in Thigpen, which meant it had been dead before.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Thigpen was decided after the petitioner in this case was sentenced.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I am talking about what the Court of Criminal Appeals said.
Didn't it say that?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Your Honor, I would say that is what they said.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Ms. Cox, I suppose in any case where the legislature has validly provided for a mandatory sentence upon conviction or habitual offenders or that sort of thing, the right of allocution, the right of the defendant to get up and speak before the jury if there is jury sentencing or before the judge if there is judicial sentencing, really is a fantasm almost if the sentence has to be mandatory.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I would have to agree with that statement, that what good would it do for the defendant to get on the stand unless he were taking the underlying conviction upon which the enhancement was laid, that for him to be presenting the mitigating circumstances, it would not affect the range of punishment because the jury had been instructed to return a mandatory sentence.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If that is constitutional, to give a lot of arguments why you shouldn't be given a mandatory sentence that is required, it isn't going to do him any good.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I'm sorry, I missed your question.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: For the defendant to give the jury or the judge a lot of reasons why a less than mandatory sentence shouldn't be imposed on him isn't going to do the defendant any good if the legislature has said constitutionally that this mandatory sentence shall be imposed.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's correct.

Of course, the petitioner argues that he should be, if he was in fact sentenced under 51(A), that the legislation should contain minimum standards in order to determine within the range of punishment that he is to have.

Of course, I really feel that the analogy in this case does not apply simply because if you have sentencing standards, as in the death penalty case, you are really looking toward the individual, and when you have discretionary sentence the jury is looking not only towards the offense but the individual offender, and the only thing that the standards and guidelines would provide in a discretionary sentence would facilitate appellate review.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did you argue this case in the Court of Criminal Appeals?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No, I did not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So you don't know any more than Mr. Ebel, I take it, except from briefs what were raised as federal constitutional issues?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's correct, I did not argue it at the trial court level.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do I understand correctly that you have agreed with your friend that the Court of Appeals of Oklahoma could have remanded that case for resentencing by a new jury?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: No.
The only thing that the Court of Criminal Appeals could do is reverse the entire case and start completely over.
They could have remanded it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If the Court of Appeals could not do it, then can this Court, could this Court remand it for resentencing?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I know of no procedure whereby the State of Oklahoma could reempanel the jury.
I'm sure this Court could, but how could the State of Oklahoma facilitate that request.
It would require legislation or a violation of this Court's order.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You say every time a judge misinstructs the jury as to the range of sentencing, where there is jury sentencing and he just makes a mistake, a Court of Appeals decides that he was erroneously sentenced, properly found guilty but erroneously sentenced, there must be a new trial?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: That's correct.

I know of no instance in the State of Oklahoma where a case has been remanded specifically resentencing except in those cases where the defendant is sentenced by a trial judge without the necessity of a jury.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It almost follows from the fact you have jury sentencing in your state.
In many states you do not have jury sentencing.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Oklahoma is unique in that, yes, and I didn't realize it until this particular case, but we do afford the defendant an opportunity to have his sentence determined by a jury.
Basically, all the state is saying is that basic due process requires a hearing on the trial court level, which was given in this case.

On the appellant level, where the court -- where the state of Oklahoma has granted a lot of review, the only thing that is required in that instance under due process is the right -- in this case the petitioner was entitled to an attorney at public expense, the right to a public transcript.

He was entitled to brief his cause and to present errors and his only expectation in the Court of Criminal Appeals was that the court would render a fair and impartial review of his sentence and look for fundamental errors.
That is all due process requires.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If we remanded and the Court of Criminal Appeals decided as a matter of state law that contrary to your view of the matter a new jury could be drawn for the sentencing only, even though that you say has not been done before, would that action of the Court of Appeals be reviewable here?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I would think so, yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What would be the federal question?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Well, there wouldn't be unless the defendant raised one if he was -- if in fact he went back and was resentenced and got a greater punishment, life, surely he would contest that it was a denial of due process possibly to send him back for resentencing.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, you said before he could get a life sentence.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Possibly if he were resentenced.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He didn't get a life sentence if he got the same sentence he has now, then would there be any federal question?

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: I know of none off the top of my head.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Assuming that the Court rejected your brother's attacks on 51(A), he presents federal questions in asserting that 51(A) itself is constitutionally invalid.

turn.speaker: janet_l_cox
turn.label: Ms. Janet L. Cox
turn.text: Yes, and that that legislation should contain minimum sentencing standards.
I believe that is a due process question.

In conclusion, the respondents, as I said before, submit that the petitioner in this case has been afforded the full panoply of the due process requirements and procedures which the laws of the State of Oklahoma create.
The Constitution of this country does not provide for a defendant to be resentenced anew.
It is not a part of the due process clause and is not protected by the due process clause.
There can be no possible conceivable relationship between the notice requirements at the trial court level and applying them to the appellate level other than what has been create by state statute.
The state would submit that there has been notice in all due process.
The petitioner also raises questions of equal protection, but this Court in Rummel last week indicated that the state has a right to create classes of individuals under the Habitural Criminal Act.
I don't feel that there is any suspect classification or any reason -- there is no procedure for anyone sentenced under 51(A) or 51(B) which would violate the procedures of the State of Oklahoma.
For that reason, the State of Oklahoma asks this Court to affirm the judgment and sentence of the Court of Criminal Appeals.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have about three minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
Just three quick comments.
I think, although we could leave it to the Court of Criminal Appeals to decide whether they could remand this to a jury or not, I think there is precedent for that.
It is a case we cite in our brief, the Epperson v. State case, where I think the Court of Criminal Appeals did just that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if we agree with you, counsel, presumably what we would do is be to vacate the judgment of the Court of Criminal Appeals and remand the case to that court and let it decide what it wants to do about it.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The second point is our discussion about the power of the Court of Criminal Appeals to modify sentences.
That has always been interpreted under the Oklahoma law as the power to modify the length of the sentence when it is excessive.
Obviously, they didn't feel this sentence here was excessive.

To my knowledge, that statute has never authorized the Court of Criminal Appeals to modify the basis for which the sentence was issued, to modify the statute under which he was tried, to change the statutory basis entirely.

Finally, in response to Justice Rehnquist's question, if Mr. Justice Rehnquist will review again the petition for rehearing, the petitioner here, specifically in the petition for rehearing, Your Honor, did complain about being sentenced under federal constitutional grounds by the Court of Criminal Appeals and did ask to have that matter remanded for sentencing in accordance with state law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What did the Court of Criminal Appeals do?

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: They denied the petition for rehearing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So there is no way of knowing whether they considered it or not.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: No, but it couldn't have been raised until the petitioner for rehearing because that is the frustration that Hicks faces here, until the Court of Criminal Appeals decided that he was to be sentenced under this new statute, the error hadn't occurred.
This is unlike the case where the error occurs at the trial level and then you can raise it at the Court of Appeals.
This error didn't even occur until the Court of Appeals handed down its final decision.
He couldn't raise --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say that was the first opportunity.

turn.speaker: david_m_ebel
turn.label: Mr. David M. Ebel
turn.text: That was the first opportunity, because we are not claiming error at the trial, we are claiming it at the appellate level.
So there was no chance to raise it except here.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.
